description.text: Stepper motor mount for the ARCS

UPDATE 19th September 2015:

Hollie has tried on the hand and is very happy with it. The socket needs more padding and to be tightened but her father will do that once they get home.
They also told me she was using the previous model quite a lot, and getting more out of it the stronger her arm became. So my next approach will be to combine the previous all nylon printed hand with covers of the full colour printed hand.

UPDATE 18th September 2015:

Due to conflicting holiday and work schedules Hollie hasn't been able to try out the hand yet. Hopefully this should change tomorrow. I've uploaded some images of the hand coated in silicone with the nylon printed prosthetic cup. My wife thought loom bands would look good and since it's for an 8 year old girl I said ok.

ORIGINAL:
So the print of Hollies hand has arrived from shapeways. It is printed in full colour sandstone. I did print one finger in full colour plastic but it didn't come out very well.
I'm currently adding a protective layer of silicone to it. The sandstone is quite brittle and grainy, so the silicone will help keep it together. I'll add a layer of epoxy to the inside to help reinforce it. It's possible to infiltrate the hand once it's printed with epoxy, but since I had to outsource printing that's something I couldn't control.

I plan on doing a similar thing with the hand once I've finished the Anthromod V2.0 parametric hand. Here the hand will be broken into sections and placed around the Anthromod 'bones'.

If you want to help me develop this hand you can donate to http://www.gofundme.com/prosthetic-hand
It really does help cover the costs of getting the parts printed.

I will add additional updates as I process the hand and eventually Hollie tries it on.

comments.text: for the longest time i have had ideas to make a functional prosthetic hand and feet after watching my grand father struggle he lost both legs and half his arm at pearl.harber i would realy like to talk to you on some of my ideas i am a great engineer and i wold like to make this a new project for Hollie

comments.author: MustangDave

comments.text:
Nice project. How much did it cost to print this?
Is the sandstone a viable material for this?
comments.author: stormychel

comments.text:
Hi stormychel
To print the coloured parts of the hand it cost £31 excl taxes and shipping.
Sandstone isn't a great material for this, so I need to reinforce it to make it last any length of time. I believe shapeways uses cyanoacrylate to fix the models, from their original porous state. Ideally I would use epoxy resin to do the same thing, which should make it a lot tougher.
I did try shapeways full coloured plastic with a single finger but the results were disappointing colour wise.
I plan to upgrade the process as technology improves, but I haven't seen a printer do as good colour as the sandstone ones.
Interesting. Will keep watching your progress!

description.text: Gear with belt clamp for driving MXL timing belt on a servo motor. Parts of the ARCS

These things were made with Tinkercad. I wanted a model of why soap bubbles are spherical. (Soap bubbles are spherical in order to maximize the volume of gas trapped while minimizing the surface area of the soap film.) These models show the surface area of different shapes with the same volume. Set contains cube, sphere, cylinder, pyramid, and torus.

Note: the torus is not exactly precise, due to the limitations of the Torus shape in Tinkercad. But it's close enough for this demonstration.

Models printed well on a Replicator 2, 0.2mm resolution, 5% fill, using rafts on the models with rounded bases. Picture coming soon.

Sliding clamp for 25 by 25 mm profiles.
This Clamp is designed so you can mount interchangeable adaptors to place any object you want to be on the profile/rail. In my case I made an adaptor for a MERCURY MOTOR SM-42BYG011-25, a web cam and few other things.
Specially useful if you only need one clamp and want to use on it different gadgets. you won't have to take off the clamp or screw/unscrew anything.
I have uploaded only the adaptor for the motor and a STEP File so you can modify the adaptor to your own needs.
You will need 3 screws M3 to mount the wheels on the clamp.

description.text:
This is a replacement handle for a 2001 Fleetwood Flair 30H Outdoor Storage / Luggage compartment. Although I'm sure it will work with other closely related models.

Literally all the original handles have broken off. These are designed to be pressed/snapped into place with moderate pressure. They work perfectly on all my compartments. I recommend above 60% infill, and on one particularly tough compartment to open I needed 85% infill for it to be strong enough.

Having built the Printable Marble Machine #1 which is hand operated, I wanted to add a motor ..... which led to the redesign of quite a number of parts.
The motor which I settled on is a Pololu 298:1 Micro Metal Gearmotor which attaches onto my plastic mount using the Pololu Micro Metal Gearmotor Bracket. This motor runs off 5V and rotates at 45rpm - just about as fast as I think the design will cope with. It is powered using a 5V DC mains power supply which came with a mobile phone - I replaced the original power connector on the power supply as I wanted to use a 2.1mm DC power jack plug and socket set. I have uploaded my rather poor video attempt here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YOaXsGhuKLQ Thanks also go to gzumwalt - he has made some cracking motorised models which motivated me to have a go at this one.

As well as the original M3 screw set - 25mm screw, two washers and a nyloc nut, you will need the following:
Pololu 298:1 Micro Metal Gearmotor
Pololu Micro Metal Gearmotor Bracket
2.1mm DC Jack socket
2.1mm DC Jack plug
5V DC power supply (I used one from an old LG mobile phone)
M3 nut and M3 grub screw for the sprocket gear.
Heatshrink tubing - always handy! The bracket comes with screws and nuts which enable it to be fixed to the motor mount - attaching the motor and bracket to the motor mount should be done before you slot this sub-assembly into the base. Print each of the parts which I have uploaded. Four of them are the same as the thing uploaded by JasonM621 : the spiral chute, chute brace, chute guide and the Gear_Lift. The other files are the ones which I have redesigned to accommodate the motor. (Or in the case of the entrance chute, to improve the way in which the ball bearings are captured and to prevent them from jumping out onto the floor). Careful inspection of the photographs and videos here and those provided by JasonM621 should be all you need to figure out the assembly but things to watch out for include making sure you have the Gear_Lift part facing the right way - the side which lay against the print bed should be facing towards the inside of the machine otherwise the tilt of the holes will be going the wrong way. Be careful when wiring the power supply and make sure that you match the +ve and -ve wires to the plug and socket. Some testing will need to be carried out to ensure the right polarity to rotate the sprocket gear in the right direction.

author: Aerophare263

description.text: This is a riff on Tig29's Display/Screen Board Clamp. I loved the idea, but I wanted to make stuff other than 90°, so here they are! These are for clamping 6mm or 1/4" panels together at 108° and 120°. Uses either M3 or #4 screws and nuts.

1. Print using your favorite printer settings. I printed at 0.25 mm layer height with about 40% infill for strength.
  2. Insert M3 or #4 screw and washer in the round end, put nut in hex-shaped hole. It is a really tight fit, but by tightening the screw all the way you can pull the nut into the hole and it will stay tight.
  3. Loosen screw to insert 6mm or 1/4" panels on either side and tighten to clamp down.

description.text: This was designed by drafting 11 students Brian and Kelvin using Solid Edge.  It was created for a multi-part toy project and inspired by a character in the Mario world.

We printed ours with the following:
Plastic: PLA
Infill: 25%
Shells: 2
Extruder Temp: 190
Bed Temp: 0
Support: FootX2.stl needs to be printed twice (unless you use the build plates). HatS.stl and BodyL.stl require support and are on a separate build plate. Build plates are provided or parts can be printed separately. NOTE: If we had more time (it's June so we don't) the students felt they would modify the design more by placing the feet further back and making the "legs" a bit thicker and the corresponding hole a bit thicker. This version is NOT ABLE TO STAND ON IT'S OWN. However we felt someone else might be able to make use of the files and modify them a bit so we are uploading it. Happy remixing! :)

This is a nice little button holder that will let you install a button in the existing holes on the top of the TOM. Saves drilling and adding more holes to your Makerbot.

Print and install.
You may need to adjust the hole diameter to accommodate for your button. Mine required a 16mm hole. In my case I had an interference fit to keep it in place as the fastening nut that came with the button wouldn't quite fit. When the button is installed in the holder all you need do is snap it into any of the holes on the top of your TOM that you have free. The little tabs work great and allow easy removal if required.

description.text:
An enclosure for a Raspberry Pi 2 model B allowing easy access to necessary ports and components. One side of the design has arms for a 25mm*25mm ebmpapst fan to clip into and a hole above it to allow air to be drawn through the board.
No fastening between the components required just push the two sides together and place on the base to hold in place.
Since cooling isn't a necessity for a Raspberry Pi there is an STI file without the hole and arms for a fan.

Ebmpapst fan used - http://bit.ly/1ICo7HE

Read more at DesignSpark http://www.rs-online.com/designspark/electronics/eng/blog/from-concept-to-mass-production-using-ds-mechanical-add-on-modules

Modeled in DesignSpark Mechanical.
To download the free CAD package click the link below -
http://www.rs-online.com/designspark/electronics/eng/page/mechanical

I printed in standard quality and got good results.

The legs as they are very thin to fit through the holes on the Pi therefore very fragile so be careful.

title: Lm8uu X Carriage with Fan Mount for Prusa Mendel

description.text:
Takes 3 LM8UU bearings.
Comes with an integrated belt tensioning system (see red carriage).
Has integrated slots for cable-ties to get a really firm grip on those bearings.
Fan mount is an option in the scad file if you don't want it.
Works great with one of my extuders mounted at an angle to maximise x travel.

Extruder mounts are intended for M4 screws.
Fan mounts, belt clamps and tension adjustment M3.

comments.text: Excellent sauce, I was able to configure it to fit an E3D by simply setting the fan mount to false and choosing 34mm for the front bearing mount separation.

comments.text: probably. The standard wade has the mount points separated by the same amount, but the filament hole is not right in the middle like it is with my extruder. If your hotend still fits through the hole in its offset location (about 3mm one way and 1 the other) then the standard wade will work fine.

Although difficult to print, this is my first shot taken at a printable airframe. The frame is primarily made of carbon fiber rods (or aluminum tubes, but wood is not recommended) of a 4mm diameter (when at 100% scale.) The fuselage is very primitive for the time being. At this point, no motor mount or battery strap is present, and servos would be glued onto the wing surface and the fuselage hub.
The wings and tail are intended to be covered in cellophane or shrinkwrap, hence the ribs.

Please note: the tail pieces are at 75% scale relative to the other pieces.

Update: Motor mount added. Mesh didn't tesselate into a solid, so I also uploaded a .step file.

title: GoPro Hotshoe Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I was not satisfied with what was offered as far as mounting a GoPro on a DSLR body. After about 15 failed prints, I decided to model my own.   
I have added rafts and supports which help make a clean print, however it will require some cleanup post print. I used .25mm Layer with 50% in fill on my Rep. 2X in Black ABS, but I'm sure other settings (as long as its medium or fine) may work as well. It fits snug on the hotshoe with no rocking and the Gopro Mounts like butter.
Solidworks, A Canon 5D Mk2, a Gopro Hero3 and a set of calipers.

description.text: Used for attaching an lm8uu linear bearing to a heated bed.

Use a block of insulating wood between the bed and the holder to prevent the holder from softening.
Again, use a cable tie to make sure the bearing is held firmly.
I use 3 of these for to support the bed.
The holder is attached to the block with 2 countersunk wood screws.
The block is attached to the bed with a single countersunk wood screw. 
This means that it is self aligning and there is no need for precision drilling.

title: Vertical Lift Bracket for The little bolt hobbit

description.text: Instead of pivoting your dremel to meet the bolt, use these brackets to attach your tool to The little bolt hobbit allowing you to slide your dremel directly up and down to meet the bolt. It should make it easier to line up your cutting wheel to the center of the bolt, and in theory, make a slightly thinner cut. Modify the settings in the scad file to match your dremel holding mount's bolt spacing and you can customize the overall length, width and the channel width where your bolts/screws slide in too. These files are only for the extension brackets. They're designed to use with The little bolt hobbit by elk, found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:23717 I came up with this idea because I had to make cuts at every other tooth for a total of 16 cuts with the 32 tooth wheel because the cutting discs I use on my dremel are a little too thick to allow 32 cuts on a M8 bolt.

title: Mostly Printed CNC Parametric Tool Holder Adapter

description.text:
I wanted an tool holder for a sharpie, but liked the idea of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:898232 , so I made an adapter for my master grip tool holder. This makes it easy to swap between a pen & the rotary tool. I made one version parametric & another specific for a sharpie in the Master grip. The Sharpie version I made uses less plastic than the parametric version & did not feel like spending the time coding this version to make it parametric.

Rev8 will probably only work for 45mm & higher diameter. I made this one for 49mm OD.

I did not even have to put a tightening bolt to use the pen. Here is a video showing my 1st pen plot printing a simple design I came up with. http://youtu.be/uzvzjpQcy2Q

comments.text: I found out the hard way: the parametric .scad file rev8 does not work if your tool holder opening is less than 29mm in diameter without editing  hard coded numbers deep in the design.
comments.author: mschrock

comments.text: Probably that hour glass design to use less plastic is probably your problem.  After looking at that again, the rev8 will probably only work for 45mm in higher OD.  I will add that to the description.  What numbers were you using & I will see if I can make a version for it?

A simple mount for the L3G4200D Gyroscope. This was designed for the Parallax Gyroscope. It should fit other L3G4200D but I have not tried them as I only have the one. The space measures 22mm x 20.3mm. So if your L3G4200D or other gyro fits in that space you are good.

You can print at any resolution but I would recommend 200 microns or better. Infill does not really matter. There is a bridge so add support if you care about a little loose strands.

Dremel Micro is a very nice little portable tool.
http://www.dremeleurope.com/gb/en/dremel%C2%AEmicro-7694-ocs-c/
Unfortunately most of the bigger brothers add-ons are not compatible with Micro, so I've decided to build some for myself:

  • a table saw
  • a table grinder
  • a drill stand adapter for Proxxon MB140/200

The design is modular (10 pieces), in order to use as small amount of filament as possible. You can just combine the modules or glue them (except the covers).
A short video with the add-ons:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0R3zlQfzsSY
Just print all 10 pieces in ABS. The assembly is highly intuitive.

This is my mod for the Cheerson CX-10 mini quadcopter.
It is based on the idea of the Parrot mini Drone "Rolling Spider", which has these kind of wheels too.
The Parrot Version costs around 100€ hence I created this one.

I have designed them with Thinkercad - if you want the STL's just tell me quick and I will upload them.

Since this is my first thing, please rate it and leave comments if you made it or just want to tell me something.

Just print out these parts (1x the mount, 2x the wheel obviously).
My settings were: 2 shells, 10%infill with PLA (the Parts are solid tho because of their small size).

Assembly:
Take the wheels and use pins to connect them to the mount by heating up the pin with a lighter and simply melt a hole into the quaders in the mount-part.
Stick your wheels onto the pins, insert them into the mount and secure with glue ( I used hot-glue), then cut off the long end of the pins with a diagonal cutter.
-fin-

Have fun!

title: Inductive z-endstop German Reprap Neo
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A inductiv endstop for German Reaprap Neo.

My original endstop had a tolerance of 0.07 to 0.08 mm. With this upgrade you will get a tolerance under 0.02mm, probably 0.01mm. The high of the first Layer varies by this tolerance with every homing of the z-axis. If you have to adjust the bed at the beginning of every print, because the high of the first layer is not correct. This upgrade is great for you.

This part is an replacment for the original endstop. There is no need for any software update or additional hardware. All you need is:

an Induktiv Sensor ( PNP Normaly open M8)
a 3-pin Connector to connect it to the printrboard
2 Screws M3 at least 10mm long (the original wont fit)
2 nuts M3

Open the back side of the Printer.
Unscrew the original endstop and disconnect it.
Assemble the inductive sensor to this part.
Shorten the wire, crimp the Connector.
Mount the assembly at the hohles, where the original switch was attached.
Connect the endstop to the board.

!Test it!

Adjust it from the front side. Use the two screws.
Close the back cover.

author: zmur766

description.text:
The kids love those foam boards and play with them alot. Unfortunately the brackets holding the handles in place brake quite alot.
So i designed this bracket to replace the broken brackets. They are designed to be printed in Nylon because they have to take quite the abuse.
Put one on each side. Then use a hammer to get them in place.

I got tired of having my clamps scrape the bottom of my heated bed, so I designed a build platform coupling. This coupling wraps around your heated bed and your glass (3mm thick) There are two full build plates one has supports in the rails for printers that have problems printing long bridges, one does not. there are also individual sections encase one breaks you don't have to print the whole thing again. Note
As this is just a test concept until it is somewhat perfected or until i can print it out myself, please be careful when installing and using this item as if made out of pla and the heated bed is heated to ABS temps it will warp, ABS should hold up a little better. Vitamins needed.
4 m3 10mm screws.
4 m3 nuts. Again This is a work in progress and has not been printed yet (printer is being upgraded), please print at your own risk. If you do happen to make one please upload your pics. As this is also a work in progress, suggestions are much appreciated, and the design will change. UPDATE
Added: Thicker rails to accommodate the glass being in further from the edge.
Added: through holes for the heated bed mount screws.
Added: supports again in the models. Supports are .5mm thick
I will upload a version without supports as well to allow Slic3r or skeinforge to do the supports.

author: nobby24

description.text:
A simple 2 ramp dice tower that can be made quickly and easily with out overhangs.

No overhangs = no scraping off scaffolding!

Translucent sides create a nice effect in a well lit environment!

• Make sure each piece is oriented such that it has no vertical overhangs.
  • Print:
    • 1 x BigRamp
    • 1 x LittleRamp
    • 16 x Pin
    • 1 x Side1
    • 1 x Side2
    • 1 x Tray
  • Super glue is strongly recommended for pins
  • Recommended 3D Printer settings:
    • Single layer walls for sides and pins (2-layer wall shown in photographs). Double layer wall for everything else
    • 5% infill
    • No supports (That's kinda the point!)
    • No rafting

author: qczek

description.text: I designed this for a New Era 59Fifty hat which has a flatter brim, but didn't have one around when I printed it out. So I tried it on my coworkers 39Thirty hat, also by New Era, that has a much more bent brim but it worked just fine. You need to push it as far as you can onto the brim to make sure it is tightly on there. Once I did this I couldn't shake it off, with GoPro attached. It is made to fit the clip that all the other attachment connect with, not the frame itself. As of now the arms are relatively thin so let me know if anyone has one break on them and I'll go back and thicken them up.

Should be relatively easy to print, just have it sitting on its side. You'll need some supports to hold up the tabs the GoPro clip slips under. I did it at 30% infill but it might be better to do 100%, it won't use much more filament.

This sliding storage system prints fully assembled with built-in supports. The model features a carrying handle for transportation when it is in its closed position.

DISCLAIMER: This model includes tight tolerances and moving parts. Make sure that you printer is well calibrated before attempting to print. There is a part file included called tolerance test which allows you to test if the model will print on your printer without fusing.

We printed ours with a 0.2mm layer height and 10% infill. Supports are built into the model and must be removed after printing. There are two models. One with 0.5mm tolerance between moving parts and the other with 0.6mm tolerance. We have included a part file called tolerance test which you can print to see which tolerance works best with your printer. We ran into issues with warping during the print which we solved by printing on glass with glue.

An elegant Vase.

Probably best results at a larger size. I recommend hi-resolution settings and make the walls 3 shells thick with 10% infill.

Made in Modo.

comments.text: How did you make this vase? Could you possibly provide an stl file for each individually colored part?
comments.author: kharar

comments.text: The coloured vase is rendered in a 3D modelling program (Modo) as an image and was not printed out that way.  It would be difficult to chop it up and provide the coloured parts as stl files. One could stop the print and change filaments at various levels to achieve a similar look but with the consumer technology that we are currently dealing with that is about as good as it gets.  Wait a few years and hopefully things will improve.  Of course, one could print the vase, mask off the sections and spray paint each part separately - that is probably the best solution for now.
comments.author: kharar

This is a remix of japhy's owl earphone wrapper which was based on eweinhoffer's version.  I modified this one to have a notch to hold the tail of the wire in place at the bottom of the left ear, added two holes into the rectangular slot so the plug stays nicely in place, and added some aesthetic and functional 'eyeballs' so you can fit the earphones through horizontally and they will stay in place vertically.  I also gave it a label in honour of my evil daughter Amelia who I had to make this for.

I get some warnings when running it through ReplicatorG.  I had a crack at fixing some dodgy triangles around the lettering and bottom-most hole, but there doesn't appear to be any actual problem in the printed product.

There is a new version available.

I use bunch of tweezers pretty often. So I decided to print a nice rack for them.

The holes in sides are for screws and screwdriver to put them in.

comments.text: Worth noting that the screws need to be M2.5 or smaller (M3 have to big heads). Also no chamfer in holes, so screw head doesn't hide in element wall which is a bit bad. Otherwise great idea. Printed.
comments.author: arekm

comments.text: I don't really know which screws I was using, just some I had laying around, with small heads. For second make I just used double-sided tape and it works just fine.

I am using a hard wired 9v battery

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=coVvKIr9SFs

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RTLtVf1SvGg <---- FINAL

FINAL UPDATE March 19th, 2016 ****

i resolved the only major issue (idlers) by removing any printed parts. i used fender washers on top and bottom of 2 bearings on a M3 x 40mm screw drilled into the upper tabletop thereby bracing it at 2 points instead of 1. now that the idlers stay perpendicular, there are no anomalies in the layers, and every line comes out smooth w/o any wobble. i've taken this project as far as its gonna go, and i'm quite satisfied w/ the results. aluminum tubing + PLA makes sense for larger builds based on this project. its not for everyone, but it is a viable alternative in my opinion. the front bearing is slightly loose and makes a bit of noise on fast moves, but the quality of the print is not affected.

here is why you should NEVER BUILD THIS THING:

the 75 x 60cm LINNMON tabletops are no longer available from IKEA, you'd have to go even bigger at 100 x 60cm. that won't affect the movement but it'll be even bigger, and this thing is already pretty ridiculous.

i don't i think posted all the right parts on thingiverse to successfully make this thing. the fact is, i have thousands of designs and can't remember which ones i printed or which ones even worked.

there is little to no maintenance for this printer, but when you DO have to access the XY steppers, it becomes a real hassle and requires a considerable amount of patience.

having said that, i really don't want anyone wasting their time on this thing. it was a proof of concept that has become my main 3D printer. i've disassembled my old printer and have designed a new frameless, smaller, more conventional 3D printer which i will post to thingiverse in the next week or so. that one is designed to be more straight-forward, has both bowden and direct, and uses 8mm shafting + LM8LUU. it uses the same movement for XY but will be much more simplified and accessibility will no longer be an issue. stay tuned, and thanks for checking this thing out.

moved temporary Z-axis to side-to-side instead of front-to-back. got some front bearing noise which i'll address soon, and still having issues on retract and fast move leaving artifacts behind. swapped out 1.7A 0.9degree/step motor for 1.2A 1.8degree/step motor for the extruder. somehow the 0.9 steppers can't keep up w/ the information being sent to them and just panic. i'll look into that too, 'cause ideally i'd want those on XY since they're much smoother. i can always change stepping to 1/8 instead of 1/16 but i'd rather understand why.

2 IKEA LINNMON tabletops connected by 4 ADILS legs. this is done by inverting the height adjustment feet. i'll explain later and consolidate the other things i uploaded into one. z-axis is temporary as are many other parts. very WIP.
don't attempt to build this thing yet until i publish a BOM.

i have a few ideas for this printer, including floating on just 1 tabletop w/o any legs... maybe even cutting a whole in the top and attempting direct drive instead of bowden. since its rather big, the sky's the limit.

for now i need to modify the platemounts to include a M3 nut the idler pin can screw into so its braced at 2 points in stead of just one (won't be pulled toward the stepper). also i already have a stepper plate w/ endstop holes at either end for endstop mounting for a cleaner design. additionally i have a belt snap in mechanism i'd like to try out in the near future. the Z-axis is very temporary and that has to get redone to use the ADILS legs as smooth rods (if possible--i failed miserably in my previous attempts). cable management, control box, and lighting will be worked on next.

ok. cleaned up files a little bit. included only files that i have on the prototype. they are not perfect, but work for now. i will include things denoted with an 'X' indicating they are experimental and should be better than my prototype originals.

what complicates matter more is that i switched unit scale between blender installations so some things might be out of scale by a factor of 100. also, early parts were designed for 0.17mm layer height, but i doubt any of those are included.

as always... DON'T BUILD THIS PRINTER YET. i'll clean it up more and test a few more parts to make it less stressful for you to build and operate.

for 0.35mm layer height only (for now). otherwise the math won't work for slot-loading nuts, etc.

BOM is just under $400 CAD:
for current setup which will likely change you'll need:

4 x 6 ft. 3/4" anodized aluminum tubing at $20/piece at home depot - $80

1 x 8 ft. 1" anodized square extrusion - $20 at home depot

LINNMON/ADILS - 2 100x60 LINNMON tabletops + 4 ADILS legs - $40 total (usually half price in their as-is section). mine is 75x60 and were $4/piece if you sign up for their newsletter or something--can't find them now though. so $40 for the furniture.

7 x NEMA 17 steppers - $140 total

RAMPS/Arduino/DRV8825/endstops - $40 on aliexpress for everything.

LED PSU - $30 also on aliexpress... but you can use a PC PSU.

screws/washers/hardware/threaded rod/wire/etc. $40 total.

so to build this WIP which i strongly discourage you from doing would cost about $400 CAD. you choose your hotend, im working w/ an MK8-type extruder but this can cost an additional $10 - $100 depending on your choice. so let's go w/ $400 CAD for now as the lowest possible price for the current build.

i don't know how much room i have here or how to link TXT files to this thing, but let me explain what you'll need for each of the 4 corners of the table top:

Platemount - screwed in by 5 IKEA screws that come w/ each ADILS leg or 5 8X1 WOOD/METAL screws you can get at Home Depot

Stepper Plate - attached to the platemount using 6 M3X12 screws and nuts

NEMA 17 Stepper - attached to stepper plate using 4 M3X12 screws

Idler - connected to stepper plate using M3 screw and M3 nut inside the platemount if you print the experimental platemounts i'll add soon. its better to have the idler M3 screw braced at 2 points instead of 1 (which is what i'm still using on the prototype)

GT2 Belt - 6mm wide belt. i can't tell you the length right now but it will vary depending on which size LINNMON you go with. this gets wrapped around the NEMA17 GT2 pulley (20 teeth) and the idler on the adjacent platemount. basically each axis pair will have one stepper going clockwise and the other CCW so the spanning bars joining them will be synced. its not redundant... trust me :)

for instructional purposes let's say each platemount has 1 aluminum bar (round profile) even though there are clearly 2 connected to each one at right angles.

so that aluminum tube will have on it:

Bearing - i'm going to redesign these a bit, because these last ones are a bit too bulky... prints still come out great, but its just unnecessary. each bearing has 4 slot-loaded M3 nuts to which the belt clips will be attached w/ M3x12 screws.

Bearing Bracket - this will hold the spanning bar between axial pairs and keep the bearings "LEVEL". the spanning bars intersect at what i'm calling the 'crosshair' which consists of 3 pieces (more on that later).

Belt Clip - each bearing has 2 belt clips to hold the belt in place. i designed a fancy snap-in system too but haven't really tested it out yet. each belt clip has 2 M3X12 screwed into them to hold the belt.

so ALL that X 4. make sure the plus9's are in opposite corners just like the minus9's. what is this plus9/minus9 you ask? well, IKEA uses a 5 screw mounting pattern. that's 360 degrees/5=72 degrees between screws on the platemount. so the screw on each leg closest to the long edge of the table is 0 degrees. we want the stepper to be at exactly 90 + 45 degrees pointing into the table. anyways... long story short, 72+72=144 and we're trying to hit 135 degrees, hence the plus9 minus9 versions of platemounts and stepper plates.

looks like i can keep writing here. GOOD.

i think you can figure out how the upper and lower crosshair go over the spanning bars. that will most likely change too as i try to counterbalance the heatsink against the fan to allow more room for the bowden tube, and therefore allow for a shorter 'bowden groovemount' -- the lowest part of the crosshair to which the hot end gets attached. i know i'm calling parts the wrong way... but just go with it for now.

the z-axis is very temporary but works very accurately despite the occasional squeak from the threaded rod. layers look very sharp. ultimately the legs might become the Z-smooth rods if i can print some bearings that are long enough and beefy enough.

haven't decided where i'm going to put the filament spool or the extruder, but i'm working on the control box for now. i'll post parts w/ correct names under the same 'thing' tomorrow and maybe even some experimental parts if you want to print those instead.

thanks for reading. let me know if you're in Europe and can't source 3/4" aluminum tubing. i'll revise my platemounts/bearings for 20mm or whatever you CAN get.

note on bearings: i print them really tight so you'll get a workout smoothing the inside through friction.

my M3 holes are always tight and need to be drilled through w/ a 1/8 bit.
